title: Putting your children first
introduction:
The needs of your children should come first when you make child arrangements with the other parent.

Your children will feel happier if they have regular contact with you and the other parent, and know where to get extra support if they need it. If they understand the situation, involve them in the decision-making.
body_intro:
The needs of your children should come first when you make child arrangements with the other parent.

Your children will feel happier if they have regular contact with you and the other parent, if it’s safe to do so. If they understand the situation, involve them in the decision-making.

includes.text: arranging times your children spend with you

title: Your parental responsibility
introduction:
Parental responsibility is a term that means you have legal rights and duties relating to your children's upbringing.

It doesn't mean you have a right to spend time with them - this is the children's right.
body_intro:
Parental responsibility is a term that means you have legal rights and duties relating to your children's upbringing.

It doesn't mean you have a right to spend time with them - this is the children's right.

includes.text: making decisions with the other parent

title: Getting emotional support
introduction:
Emotional support can help you get through the stress of making child arrangements.

You’re more likely to reach an agreement if you’re emotionally ready and know where to get support if you need it.
body_intro:
Emotional support can help you get through the stress of making child arrangements.

You’re more likely to reach an agreement if you’re emotionally ready and know where to get support if you need it.

resources.info:
Find out more about counselling

Relate has a free online chat service. Sessions last around 25 minutes.

Relate also has a telephone service that costs £55 per hour.

Getting it right for children is a free programme which uses real life situations to show how things can go wrong - and how you can do them better.

title: Use negotiation tools and services
introduction: If there are no safety concerns, the cheapest and easiest way to make arrangements is to negotiate with the other parent. There are free tools and services that can help you.
body_intro: If there are no safety concerns, the cheapest and easiest way to make arrangements is to negotiate with the other parent. There are free tools and services that can help you.
usp_callout: you both still communicate and agree on the majority of issues but may benefit from using a tool such as a parenting plan.

resources.info:
GOV.UK has information on arranging child maintenance yourself that includes a child maintenance calculator.

Separated Families also has a free online parenting plan

Tips on how to communicate with your ex

pros.text: you and the other parent are in control

cons.text: you’ll need a consent order to make agreement legally binding
process heavily relies on parent co-operation

title: Professional mediation
introduction: Mediation sessions are run by professionals who help you try and reach an agreement without going to court. It isn’t relationship counselling and you don’t have to be in the same room as the other parent.
body_intro:
Mediation sessions are run by professionals who help you try and reach an agreement without going to court.

Mediation isn’t relationship counselling and you don't have to be in the same room as the other parent.

steps.title: Find a mediator
steps.body:
Mediator rates can vary depending on their experience and your location. Some offer reductions if you're unemployed or on a low income.

Check with the mediator before booking and don’t be afraid to shop around.

steps.title: Book initial meeting with mediator
steps.body:
You must first meet with a mediator to check if mediation is right for you. This is called a pre-mediation meeting.

If you or the other parent wants to go to court this initial meeting is called a Mediation Information and Assessment Meeting (MIAM).

The parent applying to court is legally required to show they’ve considered mediation by attending a MIAM, unless they’re exempt. The other parent is also expected to attend.

At either meeting the mediator will explain:

  • how mediation works
  • the benefits
  • whether it's right for you
  • the likely costs
  • if you're eligible for free mediation through legal aid

Only authorised mediators can carry out a MIAM. Check with the mediator before you book.

costs.description: Average cost of MIAM per person
costs.small_print: Estimated fees may vary depending on your location and the experience of the mediator. Some mediators offer reductions if you’re unemployed or on a low income. It may also be cheaper if you attend together.

steps.title: Attend mediation sessions
steps.body:
Mediation usually takes place face-to-face with the other parent over several sessions. Each session lasts about 90 minutes.

You can choose to have mediation:

  • in the same room
  • in different rooms (shuttle mediation)
  • on different days
  • with your children (family mediation)
  • with a lawyer (lawyer-assisted mediation)

costs.description: Average cost of mediation per person
costs.small_print: Estimated cost based on an average of 3 sessions. Fees may vary depending on your location and the experience of the mediator. Some mediators offer reductions if you’re unemployed or on a low income.

steps.title: Get agreement in writing
steps.body:
If you both reach an agreement the mediator will write down the details. This isn't legally binding but is flexible so you can update it if your situation changes.

Making your agreement legally binding

You can ask a lawyer to draft a consent order if you or the other parent prefer to make your agreement legally binding.

This can be useful if the arrangements are long and complex or you think you need a more formal agreement with the other parent.

GOV.UK has more information about consent orders and making your agreement legally binding.

who_is_involved_caption: Cost will vary dependent on location and the experience of the mediator. How many mediation sessions you need will depend on how complex your situation is.
usp_callout: you both want to reach an agreement but need help from someone who is independent.

resources.info:
The Family Mediation Council has more information on the mediation process and how it can benefit you.

The Separated Parents Information Programme helps you understand how to put your children first and manage disputes with the other parent. There are similar programmes in Wales and Scotland.

Download a mediation information pack from the Ministry of Justice.

Advice Now has a guide to using mediation following separation.

Find out more about lawyer-assisted mediation

Find a local mediator

pros.text: it's quicker than court in most cases

cons.text: you’ll need a consent order to make agreement legally binding
process won't work unless parents can co-operate

title: Lawyer negotiation
introduction: You don’t have to deal directly with the other parent if you choose this option. You each hire a lawyer to negotiate arrangements for you.
body_intro:
You don’t have to deal directly with the other parent if you choose this option. You each hire a lawyer to negotiate arrangements for you.

It can be an expensive process but some parents find having experienced legal help reassuring.
who_is_involved_caption: Cost will vary dependent on location and the experience of the legal representative. How many hours you need will depend on how complex your situation is.
usp_callout: your relationship is still difficult and you’d prefer not to meet, or there’s a lack of trust.

pros.text: everyone is committed to not going to court
quicker and less stressful than court
you don't deal directly with the other parent

cons.text: can be seen as a confrontational approach
you may feel you're not in control

title: Collaborative law
introduction: Collaborative lawyers work with you and the other parent to resolve your issues out of court. You each hire a lawyer then all meet to negotiate face-to-face.
body_intro:
Collaborative lawyers work with you and the other parent to resolve your issues out of court. You each hire a lawyer then all meet to negotiate face-to-face.

The collaborative process involves several steps but is usually quicker and cheaper than going to court.

steps.title: Hire a lawyer
steps.body:
Both you and the other parent will need to hire your own lawyer. A lawyer will be expensive so try and get a quote or ask if they offer a fixed fee for the collaborative process.

Some lawyers offer free 30-minute consultations or you can check if you can get free legal help.

costs.small_print: Fees may vary dependent on location and the experience of the lawyer. How many hours you need will depend on your situation.

steps.title: Meet with your lawyer
steps.body:
Your lawyer will first want to meet with you to discuss the case. They'll need to know more about your situation and what you want to achieve from the process.

Your lawyer and the other parent's lawyer will then contact each other so they can plan for your first collaborative meeting.

steps.title: Attend first meeting
steps.body:
Before the meeting starts everyone must sign a contract that commits both parties to resolving the issues out of court.

The contract also states that if the case does go to court both you and the other parent must hire new lawyers. This means it’s in everyone’s interests to make sure the negotiations don’t break down.

Before you start to negotiate your lawyers will ask you and the other parent to share your priorities and concerns.

steps.title: Sign the agreement or set a date for next meeting
steps.body:
Collaborative law is a flexible process so how many meetings you'll need to reach an agreement will depend on your situation.

If you agree at the first meeting

Your lawyers will draw up a document that they'll submit to court for approval. You and the other parent won’t have to attend court unless there's an issue with the document or the judge wants more information.

If there's no agreement at the first meeting

You and the other parent must meet with your lawyers to discuss the unresolved issues. A date is then set for a second meeting.

If there's still no agreement

If it looks like you won't be able to reach an agreement, you and the other parent may need to consider going to court.

who_is_involved_caption: Costs may vary depending on your location and the experience of your legal representative. How many hours you need will depend on how complex your situation is.
usp_callout: you can still communicate with the other parent but have complex legal issues to resolve.

resources.info:
Read more about the collaborative law process

Find a collaborative lawyer

pros.text: everyone is committed to not going to court
quicker and less stressful than court
you and the other parent set the agenda
good for your children to see their parents working together

cons.text: won't work unless you and the other parent trust each other equally

title: Going to court
introduction: You’ll need to go to court if you’ve tried other suitable options and still can’t agree arrangements, or you’re worried about the safety of you or your children.
body_intro:
You’ll need to go to court if you’ve tried other suitable options and still can’t agree arrangements, or you’re worried about the safety of you or your children.

The court process involves several steps and can take a long time.

steps.title: Choose to hire a lawyer or represent yourself
steps.body:
Hire a lawyer

A lawyer will be expensive but they’ll handle the legal aspects of the case and represent you in court.

They may try and negotiate a deal with the other parent out of court or recommend you move to step 2 straight away.

Find a legal adviser

Represent yourself

You may choose to represent yourself because you'd prefer to speak to the judge directly or because you can't afford the legal fees.

GOV.UK has more information on how to represent yourself in court.

The Personal Support Unit (PSU) provides help for every stage of the court process for those without a lawyer.

Find a free legal advice clinic

costs.small_print: Fees may vary depending on your location and the experience of the lawyer. How long you need will depend on your situation. Some lawyers offer free 30-minute consultations or you can check if you can get free legal help.

steps.title: Attend a Mediation Information and Assessment Meeting (MIAM)
steps.body:
Before applying for a court order you must attend a MIAM, unless there’s been domestic abuse or social services are involved in your situation.

The MIAM will assess whether mediation is right for you and if you can agree arrangements out of court.

You will need to find a mediator to book a MIAM.

Only accredited mediators can carry out a MIAM. Check with the mediator before you book.

costs.description: Average cost of MIAM per person
costs.small_print: Estimated fees may vary depending on your location and the experience of the mediator. Some mediators offer reductions if you’re unemployed or on a low income. It may be cheaper if you attend together.

steps.title: Apply for a court order
steps.body:
Fill in the C100 form to apply for a court order and send it to your nearest family court. It costs £215 to apply.

You must give a brief summary of your position and what you want to achieve from the hearing. This is sometimes known as a ‘position statement’.

You'll need to make a separate application if you wish to discuss any other issues in court (for example your finances).

The court will set a date for a First Hearing Dispute Resolution Appointment (FHDRA). It'll take about 4 weeks after you apply to get a date.

An advisor from the Children and Family Court Advisory and Support Service (Cafcass) will provide a report before the first hearing.

A Cafcass report includes:

  • a social services and criminal record check on you and the other parent
  • details of your family's current arrangements
  • a summary of any other issues the court needs to be aware of

Cafcass will also contact you before the first hearing with more information about what to do on the day.

Watch video for more details

costs.small_print: Only applicant needs to pay the fee.

steps.title: Go to court
steps.body:
At the first hearing the court will see if there’s still a chance you can reach an agreement with the other parent.

If you can reach an agreement

The judge will end the process and write a consent order setting out the details of your agreement.

If you can't reach an agreement

The judge will look at the issues you disagree on and set out a timetable for what will happen next.

You may be asked to try and reach an agreement again. This could be through mediation or a Separated Parents Information Programme (SPIP).

Your case may be put on hold (adjourned) if the judge needs more time to decide what's best for the children. The court may ask Cafcass to write another report.

A new date is then set for a final hearing. If you reach an agreement before this date the judge can stop the process.

GOV.UK has more information on what happens if there’s no agreement at the first hearing.

who_is_involved.cost: Mediation Information and Assessment (MIAM) £90 per person
who_is_involved.xcost:
Mediation Information and Assessment (MIAM) £90 per person

Single mediation session £85 per person

who_is_involved_caption: Costs may vary depending on your location and the experience of your legal representative. How many hours you need will depend on how complex your situation is.
usp_callout: you want a court to make a decision for you or you have concerns about domestic abuse or child neglect.

resources.info:
Telephone: 01689 820272 (Resolution)
Check if you can get legal aid
Find a legal adviser
Check if you can get free legal help
Legal costs: free or affordable help

cons.text: court process takes a long time
you’re not in control - a judge will make the decision
can be more stressful for your children
increased chance of conflict between you and the other parent

title: You’re eligible to use this service
